Music|Godsons of Soul Reunite to Toot Their Horns

    Music

    Godsons of Soul Reunite to Toot Their Horns

    By LARRY ROHTEROCT. 5, 2011

    Inside
      Supported by

      Advertisement

      Continue reading the main story
      Continue reading the main story Share This Page
      Continue reading the main story
      Continue reading the main story

      Thanks to James Brown, even casual followers of rhythm and blues are on a first-name basis with the three core members of his old horn section. In one hit song after another, from the mid-1960s through the early 1970s, Brown, known as the Godfather of Soul, would address them directly, urging them on with interjections like, “Hit me, Fred!” or “Pee Wee, take it on out!” or “Maceo, all right, bring your lickin’ stick!”

      But after playing a crucial role in the invention of funk, Fred Wesley, Pee Wee Ellis and Maceo Parker have gone on to have distinguished careers on their own, both as bandleaders and as featured players with Prince, Van Morrison, Parliament-Funkadelic and others. And on Thursday night at Town Hall, they will be performing together onstage for the first time in 20 years, a reunion they are clearly relishing.

      “We jell together,” Mr. Wesley, a 68-year-old trombone player, said on Tuesday, when the men gathered to put together a set list for the Thursday show and start rehearsals. “We were educated by James Brown, who hammered certain stuff — a style and a togetherness — into us. Whether we admit it or not, we always draw from that, and somehow that makes us able to play anything together.”

      Mr. Brown had a reputation as a taskmaster averse to sharing glory, recognition or riches with his sidemen. But Mr. Ellis, the co-writer of influential tracks like “Cold Sweat” and “Say It Loud (I’m Black and I’m Proud),” and, later, Mr. Wesley held the title of musical director of the Brown band at its zenith, which, combined with Mr. Parker’s gritty, pulsating saxophone solos, enabled them to create a template for much of the popular music of the last 25 years, including rap.

      “Your general layman may not know it, but it’s difficult to put into words how important and meaningful they have been to every generation of musicians that has followed them,” said the bassist Christian McBride, 39, who will be part of the band on Thursday. “Any time you hear a remotely funky horn section, you know you are listening to something that comes directly from the legacy of Maceo, Fred and Pee Wee, with James Brown, but also on their own.”

      Advertisement

      Continue reading the main story

      The chemistry among the three men is strong and becomes obvious the instant they are brought together in the same room and begin to talk, trading stories about the old days, good and bad, on Brown’s payroll. But as musicians, they have very different styles and backgrounds.

      “When I get to the point where I start talking about percentages, I like to say that Pee Wee is 100 percent jazz, but he can play funky,” Mr. Parker, 68, explained. “Fred is like 50 percent jazz and 50 percent funky. Me, I’m 100 percent funky. When you put all that together, stir it up and mix it, it’s magical.”

      In fact, Mr. Ellis, 70, studied saxophone with Sonny Rollins in the 1950s and says that he joined the Brown band “essentially to make enough money to afford to be able to play jazz.” At one point in the 1970s, Mr. Wesley was going back and forth between the Count Basie band and Parliament-Funkadelic, which in musical terms are as different as chalk and cheese.

      Advertisement

      Continue reading the main story

      Advertisement

      Continue reading the main story

      In 1990 and 1991 the men also toured together before heading off to more lucrative work: Mr. Ellis signed on as the musical director and arranger of Van Morrison’s band, and Mr. Parker often tours with Prince. The keyboard player Larry Goldings, who will be performing in the Thursday show, was part of that trio’s early ’90s band, and has vivid memories of what he describes as an uncanny level of unspoken communication among the three onstage.

      “Because they had been a unit for so many years, it was like they were one person,” he said. “I’ve never seen three people spontaneously harmonize the way they do, and it was quite fascinating to see how instinctive they were with the parts they came up with. It was like birds traveling in a flock, so seamless when they turn left to right. It’s exactly the same way with them: they can just read each other’s phrasing in a way that is pretty breathtaking.”

      Almost a decade ago, Mr. Wesley published a memoir, “Hit Me, Fred: Recollections of a Sideman,” in which he talks about all the ways that, as he put it on Tuesday, “James Brown tried to play us off against each other, on the stage, off the stage, all the time.” Instead, those efforts at divide and conquer brought the three men together, building what Mr. Parker called a sentiment of “I care about this guy, and he can really play.”

      At some 40 years’ remove, all three men clearly have mixed feelings about their tenure with Brown, who died on Christmas Day in 2006. They talk with a mixture of resignation and resentment of all the ideas that were appropriated from them, entire songs for which they say they did not get recognition or royalties, but also credit the experience with making them better musicians.

      “We rode the bus together from town to town, stopping sometimes to record, getting back on the bus and going to the next town, to the hotel, where we would rehearse, to the next town, where we would have a sound check,” Mr. Ellis recalled. “Every day at 5 o’clock you were on the stage, playing something.”

      The funky licks created in those circumstances, and later with Parliament-Funkadelic under the command of George Clinton, have been sampled literally thousands of times by rappers over the last 30 years, which is another source of melancholy. Mr. Ellis said they were gratified by that recognition, but Mr. Parker also wondered why today’s musicians would rather use those old samples when their flesh-and-blood creators are still available.

      “I’ve always had mixed emotions about it,” Mr. Parker said. “It’s kind of good that somebody thinks you did something so good they want to use it. But you know, it’s easy to contact us. If you’re looking for us, any one of us, we’re very, very easy to find.”

      Thursday night’s show is admittedly an experiment, the result of three old friends crossing paths at music festivals and at recording sessions. If it goes well, there may be similar shows; the three are also talking about making a record together as a way of reinforcing their bond.

      “It’s almost like being on a college football team, and you win all sorts of trophies,” Mr. Parker said. “When you start reflecting back, that camaraderie is always there, a brotherhood that can’t nobody take away.”

      But Mr. Ellis added the obligatory blue note. The word “funk” “is in the dictionaries now,” he pointed out. “But whose picture is next to it?”

      A version of this article appears in print on October 6, 2011, on page C1 of the New York edition with the headline: Godsons of Soul Reunite to Toot Their Horns. Order Reprints| Today's Paper|Subscribe
